true, but the bushes in jungles are overgrown and very common. the jungle is currently the only place with bushes, so why not other biomes? the bushes in jungles are much bigger than what i was thinking but also theyre made of the same leaves as jungle trees and dont serve much purpose. where as my bushes would possibly grow berries or at least be made of new leaf blocks.

I have thought the same, i would love to see bushes in plains biomes, or forests, fruit bushes, or just basic, either way, it would add a good variation to many biomes, and i was thinking they are much to common in jungles, i was actually thinking earlier how the jungle floor is more bush than actual ground, and that has bothered me for a while (it has actually turned me off from jungles due to how annoyingly dense they are) but berries have seemed great in concept for a while

This is really only an issue early game before you have silk touch.  I think if something like glass shards is added they should serve a purpose other than just making a small amount of glass salvageable if you don't have silk touch.  Maybe you could make glass tipped arrows that are super sharp?  Maybe you could combine shards of different colors into a stained glass pane?
@ClayGoddessSari I like the idea of Stained Glass and Stained Glass Panes, that would add alot more colorful blocks to minecraft!
Maybe to add on to this the glass shards could be used to make a more clear form of glass.

Have 9 shards create a Broken Glass Block.  Easily breakable if placed.   To return it to it's former glory, throw it into a furnace to make a regular glass block.

 

Neat idea, but this would require 17 shards to account for the various colors.
I like this idea, also BTW its in a mod called Quark.
Now that's reduce, reuse, recycle in Minecraft, that's awesome.

Glass blocks should be crafted from a 4x4 format recipe of 4 glass shards instead of 9. You should also get back 4 shards when a glass block or pane is broken, so that you can recraft the glass block or pane again. This makes it fair and ensures the glass block is recoved.

You could also have the glass blocks drop a glass shards item 20% of the time, then one glass shards item can be smelted into a block of glass in a furnace or blast furnace. That might make more sense than being able to craft the shards back together.

I agree, but it should take 4 shards per block, and like glowstone, it gives you 2-4 shards, which can be crafted into a cracked glass block and that can be smelted into regular/stained glass, the glass pane recipe should now give 16 panes for 4 pieces of glass and when a pane is broken, it has a 75% chance of dropping a shard.
1 glass block = 4 shards or 1 bottle, so also, when a splash or lingering potion is thrown, it also drops 1-3 glass shards, not enough to make another bottle, but some of the material.

i would like if 4 glass shards are put on a crafting bench you get cracked glass, that glass will break if something stands on it and smelting it will make it regular glass, also smelting glass related things should also give you glass shards (i dont think there should be colored glass knowing minecraft logics)

I like Mark Abernathy's suggestion of using the glass shards to craft a cracked glass block. That would be really neat for builders looking to give their builds a broken/abandoned look.

Here's another idea to give the glass shards some more use: you should be able to place the glass shards on the ground as a block. Stepping on them will cause you to take damage. This would be a nice alternative to berry bushes that doesn't require grass, and also have a completely different look that would, again, be great for builds going for a run-down/messy look. Stained glass shards could also be used as a stand-in for small crystals in cave-themed builds.

I love this idea! I actually thought about this, as I thought using Blackstone to make a normal furnace was weird, but I didn't think about this!

I like this idea, but I feel like it should be slightly harder to craft. Y'know, give a bit more reason to still want to craft a normal furnace out of Blackstone (mainly if you were to start in the Nether).

Maybe it could require 3 or 5 Gold Ingots, similar to the Blast Furnace? That would also give it some nice Gold accents. It could also need to be made with Polished Blackstone, which isn't more expensive, but would take an extra step, and further differentiate it from a normal furnace crafting recipe.

(I also briefly considered that it could require a Netherite Ingot, but it'd have to be a lot better for it to be that expensive xD)

It should cool slower, as the soul flame had a lower light level than ordinary flame.
392799151231 you're right. the only fuel we have is sticks and blaze rods.

I'm going to be honest I thought of this but was planning on going in a very different direction, what if the furnace/forge had an extra slot for a bucket and when there is a bucket in the furnace it would start smelting 8 metal ore at a time and when it's done you would get a bucket of molten gold/iron in the output slot (these could be placed by dispenser). You could place the liquid and it would act like lava except if you place water next to it it would turn into a gold/iron block. This would mean you would get an extra ingot for every 8 peices of ore. It would still work like you said without a bucket, I just thought we needed a furnace with more functionality that made mining metals fun.

You can use Lava as a fuel source, and you can find iron in loot chests and from Bartering with Piglins to make Buckets, so the Nether isn't really suffering from a lack of fuel.

And while Blue Fire does give off less light, it actually deals twice as much damage, indicating that it's hotter than normal Fire.

An intresting idea would be to make the soulfire furnace necessary for smealting neatherrack into neatherack bricks and possibly other neather ores as well as being able to use the neather varients of wood as fuel.

possible texture for it:


Also, I think that they could smelt only every object except Food or Minerals.
Perhaps it could be used to smelt the new Nether Gold block, providing a full ingot when smelted as opposed to nuggets. This would reward players with silk touch.
As an addition to this, I feel like sandstone furnaces should also be a thing. It could cook things slightly slower but act as a stronger light source.
I had a similar idea but the Blackstone furnace should smelt the "miscellaneous" category of items quicker then the normal furnace.
how about two item slots?

While I like the idea of it cooking faster and giving off less light, I still think it should be different. Blackstone Furnaces should simply be a design for furnaces made with blackstone, although it could make it more blast resistant. Whether or not the fuel source is from the overworld or the nether should determine whether the flames are red or blue. Things cooked with blue fire could still be made to cook faster and emit less light

In fact, it should just be a new kiln variant, without the need for Soul Sand/Soil.

However, maybe the Soul Sand/Soil could be used to upgrade the furnace (regular and blackston, smoker and blast furnace).
Namely, the improved furnace would have the texture of a blue fire (which is hotter), which would allow it to use tree-fungus as fuel and slightly speed up its burning out.
Or just 8 blackstone, and it simply looks like soul fire...
Should come with Blackstone tools which would be a bit more durable than stone. Possibly more wood variants of chests too.
I want this too. I have a large minecart run in build I would like to take through a portal into the nether to continue it and back. Would be amazing. Make it happen!!!

I Agree 378441149052 having this would be extremely helpful, minecarts are one of the fastest way of travelling. But, one big reason why going through the nether and keeping momentum is that you cannot place rails in the portal. So the game thinks the minecart has gone ‘off rail’. So to make it work you will need to be able to place rail IN the portal.

I would love for this to happen. If this happened, I could make a roller coaster in Minecraft that goes like this: It starts out in the Overworld, but after a little while it goes into a Nether Portal while maintaining its velocity and position. Right now, if you were to try to do this, you would have to eject right before hitting the portal blocks and then get back in the cart once you're in the Nether.
A Hando, you wouldn't have to place rails in the portal because you would just have to place powered rails going right into the portal. This will get it close enough for the teleportation to happen.

I’m currently making a rollercoaster and I want it to go through the nether without having to get out of the Minecraft then going into the portal to then start the portal again this would be really helpful and I think that it should be added

This would be a very useful addition to Minecraft however I would add that if it were possible to ride in a minecart through a nether portal then the player should be capable of going through a nether portal whilst mounted on any mount such as horses and boats.

I agree! I also would like to point out, for Java 1.16.2 PR 2 the banner on the website ( https://www.minecraft.net/en-us/article/minecraft-1-16-2-pre-release-2 ) shows a pig, in a minecart, going through a portal INTO the nether.

 

This has always been a pet peeve of mine, the Minecraft marketing/pictures FROM Mojang/Microsoft never line up with the game. The aesthetics of the textures in trailers, the clear disconnect between all things minecraft(give us rare mobs you cowards, why should World get muddy pigs but not us?) It's kind of a little frustrating.

Rails can be waterlogged in Bedrock and will be able to be waterlogged in Java in 1.17...

What if it were possible to have portal-logged rails? Rails being able to go through Nether and End portal panes would be awesome and so useful!

It doesn't make a whole lot of sense that entities can traverse portals alone but entities with riders cannot.

To those saying the need for rails to go through a portal, this isn't necessarily the case. You can already send empty (without passenger) minecarts through portals so long as the rails line up on the nether side with the overworld side. There's no need to make it complex with rails going "in" the portal. 

This would be HUGELY beneficial to mob farms, redstone machines, player travel, and mob transportation to be able to transport minecarts, boats, etc with passengers through portals. I'd really like to see this.

Shulkers for instance can go through end gateways in a minecart already so the ability is there.

Also nice catch on the 1.16.2 pre-release image! The flipping picture shows the possibility! 😂 Make it reality Mojang!

It would be useful if there was another line on the HUD that showed the game time.  If the time span from dawn to dawn is a set time in real time, it would be nice to have the game time shown on the clock with certain times set for dawn and dusk.  This is useful when you're indoors or underground and do not or cannot tell what time it is.  One could carry a clock, but this would be useful as is the current coordinates are.
It would be nice to know how far from the spawn/respawn point is from the current coordinates on the HUD.  Or just the coordinates of where your next spawn point is (world or last bed).

Clocks should also tell you when it's time to sleep. 

It would be cool if you can make a large clock, similar to framing multiple maps, for decoration in a town. Like a clock tower.

This is what i have been thinking for a very long time!
The game has no way to solve this issue apart from the spammed lights and building on rare and ugly mushroom biomes!

Everyone should definitely up vote this, thank you :)

Agreed.  If I've gone deep enough in the game that I have a beacon, issues of actually keeping mobs from spawning are moot.  I can make as many torches as I need at that point, it's only a question of ruining the look of the build.

Perhaps the two levels should be to prevent mob spawn, and to prevent them from wandering in from outside the area.
I was about to suggest this but then I saw your post, hope this gets upvoted.

I thoroughly agree! As one of thousands who loves being creative in survival, I already have to give up every third night to prevent phantoms from spawning, and the nights I do get to stay up are not all that enjoyable. Having to put fencing up all around an area to keep mobs out is understandable, and if they manage to find a way in, OK, it's on me. I'll clean up the mess. But to have to lose out on all that the night has to offer to prevent hostile mobs from spawning should be addressed. I have had to put light sources everywhere in my towns and outlying areas. Some sea lanterns, some glowstone, a bunch of torches, so yeah, there's variety, but there's no night!

Can I enjoy a moment of contemplation as I watch the soft glow of the moonlight reflect over a river, without having to hear growling over my shoulder? Can I climb to the top of the bluffs and watch the sky gradually brighten as the sun rises over the ocean without that all-to-familiar, and annoying, sssss... BOOM! catapulting me into the water below? Can I go for an evening walk through the trails between neighboring towns, my path only dimly lit from distantly spaced lanterns as I weave my way through a modest forest, then enjoy the magnificence of the contrast of stepping out of the darkness toward a blazingly lit quartz palace that almost touches the clouds, without skeletons' arrows rocketing past me?

Can I? Can I enjoy the night by letting my imagination run wild as I fully explore and relax under the stars, in a place my imagination sees, or in a place I have seen in real life years ago, and hope to recreate in my realm?

So much has been implemented to assist creativity in survival but the night has yet to reach half of what it can become. It's not just a time for when the drowned emerge from the water craving battle. It's not just a place where specters from our nightmares become a reality and force us to keep sharp blades at the ready. There have been many videos posted of all the day has to offer, from beaches with colorful umbrellas made from beds to town market squares decorated with pastel-colored wool overhead like streamers. Yet our castle's secret back room corridors and underground dungeons can't be as foreboding as in the movies, there's no persistent, spooky silence where only the echoes of our own footsteps can be heard in barely-lit cobblestone tunnels, and the vast arctic doesn't feel any more desolate and hopeless under a new moon than it does in full sunlight.

Please consider Tim's idea of allowing a device like beacons to be crafted, movable, and usable in survival to prevent hostile mobs from spawning within defined areas. Let the night and darkness evolve into just as potent of a canvas as the daytime.

Thanks!
Yes! I hate that you have to spam torches to secure your base, this way there's actually an incentive to get the beacon (don't care much for the other effects).
I generally want survival to be harder, but I completely support this. At some point, the player deserves to have a base they can hang out about safely.

Beacons need this ability. We need the ability to prevent phantom spawns automatically without having to obstruct the sky with glass, lights, or other blocks. Beacons should also have the ability to prevent passive mob spawns within their radius so that you can prevent animals from spawning in your yard without covering the grass.

This makes so much sense, not just from a gameplay perspective, but from a "physics" perspective as well. Hostile mobs are afraid of light sources, and a beacon beam would realistically be the brightest light source in the game, being visible from so far away.

A beacon is a block that projects a light beam skyward, and can provide status effects such as Speed, Jump Boost, Haste, Regeneration, Resistance, or Strength to nearby players and there all nearly useless by the time you kill a wither to make one .. I've play survival for years and only used haste like 2 times cuz I've had max gear and tools by the time I get one .. so I think this idea is the best I've seen so far, plzz add this in.... ..no more iron golems trying to kill monsters under ground and getting stuck .. no more toruch spamming.. no more creepers spawning in my sheep pen (HOW DO THEY GET IN THERE lol ) ... beacon that is end game useable .. this is an amazing thing to add .. along with some other new beacon effects possible...I would run to get a beacon for the frist time in years ;) if this was in game ...ps if you add this you will get unlimited luck and love ;) ..
Minecraft really needs this! An excellent solution to the mob proofing problem in end game.

I want this but it does have to affect entire chunks around the beacon

Maybe 8 or 16 radius around the beacon, it could be an unique effect of netherite since it's so expensive to begin with.

It should definitely work in ALL dimensions!

Feeding a netherite ingot to the beacon could unlock this

I love this idea, however I think an entirely new block/item should be added to the game for this purpose. It should be something you have to craft and probably require a block of netherite along with other items that are difficult/time consuming to obtain. It should also cover a vast area e.g. a radius of 50-100 blocks I'd prefer something that doesn't beam light into the sky if possible although I have no problem with it emitting light of some kind. I think it would be especially cool if it was animated similar to the conduit!!
Yes, some way to prevent hostile spawns aside from putting torches everywhere is greatly needed.
Could even be with connected 4 beacons in a square together and everything inside of that square would be mob-spawn-proof

Uh, guys …

I'm as in-favour of other ways of preventing spawning but beacons are disruptive lighting in their own right. Sure, a lot of builds it'll be fine, but a lot of builds it won't be. 

As far as it needing to be an end-game item… no? If it has the same area of effect as a torch it may as well be same difficulty to achieve as a torch – say a stick and an iron to build a "ward", that's all. Torches already prevent mob spawning – that's not an "end game" thing. We just need a way to do that without light, and that doesn't have to be hard to achieve?

I like this. I think the beacon should require at least a block of netherite in the pyramid for this effect to work. The effect should be applied to the regular, level dependent beacon area of effect.

I was going to make a post suggesting my take on the same idea, but as soon as I typed in the title it suggeted I just vote for this one instead... so I'll vote for this and leave a summary of my idea in quotes below.

With the world getting bigger in 1.17, making effective mob farms or making sure your builds won't get swarmed with hostile mobs becomes just that slight bit more difficult.

There are two ways to deal with this currently, either cover the area in light source blocks like torches or sea lanturns, or cover the area in blocks that mobs can't spawn on like redstone or bottom half slabs. Both of these methods have the same problem though, torch spam or overuse of blocks like carpets can be (for lack of a better word) ugly, not fitting in with the surrounding enviroment or a possable esstetic that the player may want to construct.

I believe beacons should be able to prevent mobs hostile to the player from spawning in their effected area. I'm not saying that you should be able to place down nine iron block, a beacon and spend an iron ingot to achivie this. I think the best way to balance this would be to have it as a level 4 beacon effect, so the player must choose between a level 2 effect, Regeneration 1, or hostile mobs not spawning in the area.

I don't think this would be particulary overpowered as the player would be giving up a level 2 effect or Regeneration 1 for this effect, and a beacon still requiers a nether star from beating the wither.

I think this could be cool, but I understand why it's limited. Chickens and such don't have player head sized things so it wouldn't make quite as much sense. That being said, I'd love to see head added for these mobs:

- Endermen & Spiders (the only two classic enemies that don't currently drop their heads)
- Zombie & Skeleton variants (Bogged, Husk, Stray)
- Bonus points if we could get it for Blazes as well.

Thanks Mojang for making a game that's so great that people are still excited about it over a decade later.

I think instead of the light level increasing w/ the day/night cycle, the block should generate on ceilings and cause skylight to pour in below it as if there were no solid blocks obstructing the sunlight from the surface.

Would make sense since it's called Sunstone, and would create a lighting mechanic not really seen in blocks, increasing sky light instead of block light levels. Would also create cool and tall pillars/shafts of light within the caves that generate Sunstone, which would look very atmospheric.

Maybe the dyed redstone would not connect to trails of drastically different colors? Like orange connecting to both red and yellow, but never to purple. That would make it useful for complex circuits in confined corridors. Or just some nice looking wiring.

Dye using cauldron.
Right click on dyed water in cauldron having Redstone dust in hand.
Can dye up to 1 stack per click/water level.
Dyed Redstone dust can be washed back to normal by right-clicking on non-dyed water in a cauldron, or on water source.
Dyed Redstone dust cannot connect to different-colored dust on the sides, but can connect if they are on a straight line.
(optional) 2 different colored dusts can cross on the same block and remain independant circuits.
Different colored Redstone will make circuits easy to understand.
By not connecting to different colors on the sides, contraption footprint will decrease.
Powered blocks can power any Redstone dust nearby as usual.

Excellent ideas all around. My take on the tridents is this: add Sharpness, but not Smite or Bane of Arthropods. That way, the Trident would have its own water-mobs-exclusive damage-increasing Impaling enchantment; Swords and Axes would have their two above-ground-mobs-exclusive damage-increasing enchantments, Smite and Bane of Arthropods; meanwhile, all three weapons would have access to the weaker but all-purpose damage-increasing Sharpness enchantment. That seems well-balanced to me.
Who said anything about sweeping edge being worthless?  I only said that it doesn't make sense for axes or tridents, because it doesn't.  It is an enchantment for the slicing weapon, the sword.
The trident should be just as strong above ground as it is under, for there is already a lack of weapons. Also it would be a nice alternative to swords.

With an anvil, we should have the choice for the Trident:
Impaling or Power or Sharpness or Smite or Bane of Arthropods (mutually exclusive)

Same for the sword:
Impaling or Sharpness or Smite or Bane of Arthropods (mutually exclusive)

Being able to found "1.13's impossible enchantements's items" in some rare chests (from donjons or so), examples:
Axe/Trident/Bow/Hoe with Looting enchantment,
Sword/Trident with Fortune enchantment,
Tridents do actually need sweeping edge. They currently lack the ability to properly deal with grouped enemies up close in any version of the game, & sweeping would fix that nicely.

To people advocating for Tridents (and Axes) to have Sweeping Edge... Tell me, how often do you see people with battle axes or pronged stab-weapons sweeping them sideways effectively in battle? Take your time, I'll wait.
*Crickets chirping.*
@riptor werewolf, I know that's not effective in real life, but Minecraft isn't real, & the lack of sweeping edge holds tridents back from being a viable weapon.
367138775412 Axes don't have sweeping edge and they're still a viable weapon.
Knockback especially should be an option for axes. Axes are designed to maximize damage per hit, which makes pushing your opponent back way more useful on them than swords.
